history.content:
In this case, I feel it'd be best if you directly contact your advisor, since it is a case specific to your situation.

Also, just giving my two cents,

the rigor of courses at Berkeley is unmatched. I am an international student and I covered the material in Physics 7AB in my high school as well (in fact, I think most students in the US who take the AP Physics tests are on the same boat) yet I did not do as well as I'd have liked in these courses. In case you find these courses too easy, you can still choose to take them alongside courses you otherwise want to take, since they wouldn't affect your workload adversely anyway (if you know the material inside out).

In this case, I feel it'd be best if you directly contact your advisor, since it is a case specific to your situation.

children.subject: +1 I did really well in 7B objectively after having taken all 4 AP Physics classes and exams, but it was far from easy-- say what you want about Cal, but the place takes education very seriously

+1 to the Students' answer.  I think a lot of students have touched on PHYS 7A/7B topics in high school, but it's so much more rigorous at UC Berkeley.  You could have taken AP or community college to *possibly* pass out of these classes (not sure about this, check Berkeley Engineering website), but in my opinion, simply claiming "I covered it in high school" is not very official, standardized, or fair. Maybe an exam to pass out of a class might be a more fair approach, but I don't think this exists.

history.content:
Take the new H7 series, AKA 5ABC along with the labs, if you think that you know it all. 

I thought I knew a bunch of physics before I got here. Then I took those courses and realized that there is big difference between thinking you know physics and actually knowing physics. I hope those courses are still as strong as when I took them. There really is no such thing as knowing physics too well.

children.subject:
On the contrary, I found PHYS 7A/7B and MATH 53/54 to be my "lightest" tech courses in terms of homework and labs (engineering courses had far more time consuming problem sets/projects/labs).  However, I found the PHYS 7 exams to be challenging and I had to really know my theory/concepts + do lots of studying to get A's on those exams.  I also attended every lecture.

I'm happy to hear the anon above could do well with her/his high school background and ace the exams without attending lecture. I know the difficulty of a course can vary drastically depending on the instructor.  For reference, I took 7A with Prof. Zettl and 7B with Prof. (former Chancellor) Birgeneau.  Prof. Birgeneau's exams were fairly straight-forward actually, but Prof. Zettl's exams were really challenging in my experience!

You can use Ninja Courses and Rate My Professor to see what previous students have to say about an instructor's teaching style, though usually these rating websites are skewed to extreme opinions.
Yes. I agree that it might be very much dependent on the professor. I took 7A with professor Andrew Charman.

I am also an international student, but contrary to what the above anons haves suggested, I found the physics 7A course much easier than the physics curriculum I had in high school. Basically I didn’t go to any of the lecture and still aced top 3% of the exams. The most time consuming part was the Mastering Physics homework. There were so many numerical computations and the questions were super long. The labs also took me some time. So even if you are very confident about your physics, you will probably still need spend much time on it.

history.content:
Hi,

I am an EECS major and an international student. In my high school curriculum, I have finished everything in Phyics 7A & 7B. I talked to my advisor if I could just pass out of them, but she said this is not possible because of ABET requirements. Not that Berkeley has decided to cut off from the ABET requirements, can I please take something else I am interested in? If I could pass out of this, I could have a serious chance of minoring in BioE or take more upper-div courses.
history.subject: Can I pass out of Physics?
